title: 113_hr3463
content: The "Border Patrol Pay Reform Act of 2013" may be cited as the short title. The Act addresses the Border Patrol rate of pay. The "Border Patrol Pay Reform Act of 2013" aims to strengthen U.S. Customs and Border Protection, ensure Border Patrol agents are ready for necessary work, and have the flexibility to cover shift changes. It also establishes the Border Patrol rate of pay, defining terms like "available to work" and "Border Patrol agent." The term 'available to work' for a Border Patrol agent means being accessible for unscheduled duty as needed. A Border Patrol agent is defined as someone performing functions under position classification series 1896. Covered border patrol activities include detecting and preventing illegal entry and smuggling. The term 'available to work' for a Border Patrol agent means being accessible for unscheduled duty as needed, including detecting and preventing illegal entry and smuggling of aliens, goods, narcotics, weapons, or contraband into the United States, making arrests, attending training, and performing administrative duties or mission critical work assignments while maintaining law enforcement authority. The term 'available to work' for a Border Patrol agent means being accessible for unscheduled duty as needed, including detecting and preventing illegal entry and smuggling of aliens, goods, narcotics, weapons, or contraband into the United States, making arrests, attending training, and performing administrative duties or mission critical work assignments while maintaining law enforcement authority. The term 'level 1 border patrol rate of pay' refers to a rate 1.25 times the hourly rate of basic pay for a Border Patrol agent, while 'level 2 border patrol rate of pay' is 1.125 times the hourly rate of basic pay for such agent. The term 'work period' refers to a 14-day biweekly pay period. Border Patrol agents can elect to be assigned to the level 1 border patrol rate of pay (1.25 times basic pay), level 2 border patrol rate of pay (1.125 times basic pay), or decline both rates within 30 days before each year. Border Patrol agents can elect to be assigned to the level 1 or level 2 border patrol rate of pay, or decline both rates. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management will establish procedures for this election, and U.S. Customs and Border Protection will provide information on the available options to agents. Failure to make a timely election will result in consequences for the Border Patrol agent. Border Patrol agents must be informed about the available election options for the level 1 or level 2 border patrol rate of pay. Failure to make a timely election will result in automatic assignment to a specific rate. Congress recommends that no more than 10% of agents decline the assigned pay rates. Level 1 border patrol agents work 5 days a week, with 8 hours of regular time per day. Border Patrol agents who elect the level 1 border patrol rate of pay work 5 days a week, with 8 hours of regular time per day and 2 additional hours of scheduled overtime. They receive pay at the level 1 rate for regular time and do not receive additional compensation or compensatory time off for scheduled overtime. The Border Patrol agent, under certain conditions, will not receive additional compensation or compensatory time off for work described in subparagraph (A)(ii). Hours available to work during a work period will be included in regular time or scheduled overtime. They will receive compensatory time off or pay at the overtime hourly rate for hours worked over 100 in a work period. Leave will be charged in 8-hour increments for 1 shift of leave. The Border Patrol agent will be scheduled to work 5 days per week, with 8 hours of regular time per day and 1 additional hour of scheduled overtime each day. They will receive pay at the level 2 border patrol rate of pay for regular time work and will not receive additional compensation for scheduled overtime work. Leave will be charged in 8-hour increments for 1 shift of leave. The Border Patrol agent will not receive additional compensation or compensatory time off for scheduled overtime work. Any hours available to work during a work period will be included in regular time or scheduled overtime. They will receive compensatory time off or pay at the overtime hourly rate for hours worked over 90 hours in a work period. Leave will be charged in 8-hour increments for 1 shift of leave. The Border Patrol agent will be scheduled to work 8 hours per day, 5 days per week. Any available work hours during a work period will be included in the regular time scheduled. They will receive compensatory time off or pay for hours worked over 80 hours in a work period. Leave will be charged in 8-hour increments for 1 shift of leave. Border Patrol agents will receive compensatory time off or pay for hours worked over 80 hours in a work period. They are eligible for premium pay for night work, Sunday, and holiday pay, but not for any other form of premium pay. Pay received at the level 1 or level 2 border patrol rate is treated as basic pay. Overtime work for Border Patrol agents is determined according to specific sections and is not eligible for other premium pay. Pay received at certain rates is considered as basic pay for various purposes. The U.S. Customs and Border Protection has the authority to require overtime work as needed, including during emergencies. Border Patrol agents may be required to perform overtime work as needed by U.S. Customs and Border Protection, including during emergencies. Overtime work is defined for agents assigned to the level 1 border patrol rate of pay, with pay at the overtime hourly rate for approved hours exceeding 100 in a 14-day period. Border Patrol agents assigned to the level 2 border patrol rate of pay may receive pay at the overtime hourly rate for hours exceeding 90 in a 14-day period. They are also eligible for compensatory time off for any additional overtime hours worked. Border Patrol agents at the level 2 border patrol rate of pay may receive overtime pay for hours over 90 in a 14-day period. They can also get compensatory time off for any extra overtime hours worked. Border Patrol agents can receive overtime pay for hours over 80 in a 14-day biweekly pay period. They may also receive compensatory time off for any additional overtime hours worked, with a limit of 8 hours of compensatory time off per pay period unless a waiver is approved in advance by U.S. Customs and Border Protection. Border Patrol agents can receive compensatory time off for overtime work, with a limit of 8 hours per pay period unless a waiver is approved in advance by U.S. Customs and Border Protection. Additionally, Border Patrol agents may not earn more than 240 hours of compensatory time off in a year and must use any accrued hours within 1 year. Technical and conforming amendments are made to the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 to include Border Patrol agents as eligible employees for compensatory time off. The amendment (29 U.S.C. 213(a)) adds Border Patrol agents as eligible employees for compensatory time off under the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. Border Patrol agents are now eligible for compensatory time off under the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938.
